Description: Solid-cast figure of standing man, performing a ritual, in copper alloy; priest with close-cropped hair, wearing short striated kilt; priest in a striding pose, standing on small rectangular base; holding an object, perhaps a small offering tray (?) or a lamp in his left hand; if identification of lamp correct, priest lights it up with his right hand; luminary rituals are well-known but the identification of the lamp is uncertain; bronze with dark brown patina; worn off features; complete.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The figure originated from a bronzes cache discovered at Tel el Barud near Naukratis, in 1885 (on this assemblage see the comments of Griffith in Gardner 1888, 81; see also: Weiss 2012, 445-446; Masson forthcoming), though the museum's register states that it was found in Naukratis. On bronze figures of priests: Mendoza, B. 2008. Bronze Priests of Ancient Egypt from the Middle Kingdom to the Graeco-Roman Period, BAR international series 1866, Oxford (cat. no. 50, pl. 64 for this specimen). Gardner, E. A. 1888, Naukratis. Part II (Sixth Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Masson, A. forthcoming, ‘Naukratis: Egyptian offerings in context’, in M. Bergeron and A. Masson (eds), Naukratis in Context II: Cults, Sanctuaries and Offerings. Proceedings of the Second Naukratis Project Workshop held at the British Museum, 22nd – 23rd June 2013. Weiss, K. 2012, Ägyptische Tier- und Götterbronzen aus Unterägypten : Untersuchungen zu Typus, Ikonographie und Funktion sowie der Bedeutung innerhalb der Kulturkontakte zu Griechenland, Ägypten und Altes Testament 81.
Bibliographic references: Mendoza 2008 / Bronze Priests of Ancient Egypt from the Middle Kingdom to the Graeco-Roman Period (cat. no. 50, pl. 64)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (MB.268) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
